dialogue: Kites... Wood-burning set... AM Radio Kit... Oh man, who buys this crap?
Yeah, you made us march in that Gay Rights Parade.
Mom, we like your joke, but please stop saying it over and over.
“Stupid Lisa Garbageface!"  I can’t stand this any longer! Somebody please pay attention to me!
Hello! Look at me! I’m Bart! I’m Bart! Look at me! etc.
I feel like a big sissy, but I’1l help -Okay?  Look at me, I’m helping, I’m helping! Look at me!
Oh, man. They are gonna eat this up at Show & Tell.
I gotta find something for Show & Tell. Where's that stupid clay cat you
Boys and girls, Mrs. Krabappel, I come before you today to answer a question that has plagued mankind for centuries -
be jumping for joy the day but now all I have is this
my plan to get him fired. lved a series of
Mufft be a co-in-fa-dince. Say, Ned, I saw you patching the cracks
Actually, I like Ned. He's made school a lot more fun for us troublemakers.
He's not sad and lonely! I saw him in the laundromat, and he asked me to come over to his house and hang out. (OFF
I thought I heard someone say your name in the cafeteria, but they might've been saying "skim milk."
Say, Ned, somebody told me you used to play the piano... Bart reaches to take a piece of candy. Ned slaps his hand.
Because Ned is making me write this stupid essay. Plus, he gave me 2 months detention.
If there was some way to get rid of Flanders, would you want to come back?
Yeah, it wouldn't be right: you, a principal, and me, a troublemaker.
Milhouse, d'you ever think about the people in those cars?
Sometimes I wonder about all the people in this town. Do you think anything interesting ever happens to them? I mean, there must be thousands of great
Forget it. C'mon, it's 11 o'clock. I need some sugar. They walk off the bridge and over to the Kwik-E-Mart .
Well, Milhouse, I guess interesting stuff does happen to people in
Disemboweler 4, the game where condemned criminals dig at each other with rusty hooks.
Hey Lis, I found a big caramel deposit at the small of her back!
Why would anybody want to touch a girl’s butt? That’s where cooties come from.
And the dog in the Coppertone ad? Same deal, Dad?
It’s just hard not to listen to TV. It’s spent so much more time raising us than you have.
Le v8 juice isn’t one-eighth gasoline. r HOMER 0 Koppel is a robot.
Big deal. They didn’t approve my idea. They said it was "unfeasible."
Well, um, yeah. I guess they’d probably want to be with their families or something, huh?
That is a joke, right? And what, then she thought your dad’s name
I’ll get even with whoever did this to you, boy. I swear it.
Look what he did to my best friend! Everyone turns to look at Milhouse, who is eating a bag of cheez doodles and has orange powder all over his face. He looks up to see the crowd staring at him.
No, my dog! There is a hushed, mortified silence as Santa’s Little Helper  wheels himself SQUEAKILY down the aisle. The silence is broken by...
You twisted old monster! ! Bart rushes at Mr. Burns.

D.N.A., positive I.D. -- Those won’t hold up in any court -- Run, Dad! Bart tries to push Homer out the door, but instead pushes him into an entering Lou, who wears a rubber glove and is carrying a pistol.
ak -. When. she swallowed. that quarter, he -gpent all day with her.
Wow, Dad, you took a baptismal for me. How do you feel? Homer looks slightly beatific.
There was a bunch of old paint cans in their garage, though.
What are you waitin’ for? Wreck the school. You know you wanna. The devil wrestles with his conscience. Impatient, Bart scurries around to the devil’s other shoulder and whispers in that ear.
I agree. Destroy the school. The devil shrugs and begins destroying the school.

But Mom, it's just a beautiful act of respect between two consenting monsters... With a GRUNT, Marge twists Bart's head away. Every building in sight is covered with the shadows of monsters having sex.

Well, except for Chubsy-Ubsy over there. Bart points. ZIP PAN to the one remaining monster, Lard Lad, who seems to be regaining his strength. He's holding a crudely lettered sign that says "Now With Sprinkles!" as he waggles his giant donut nticingly.
Oh, the only thing left to do is to go into my dream and force Willie into a final showdown. You stay awake, and if it looks like I'm in trouble, wake me up.
Come on, Willie. I know you're out there. After a beat, a tractor with Willie's face, plaid chassis, and a menacing mowing attachment SMASHES through the hedge behind Bart and nearly runs him down.
Willie's gone for good. Now I can get back to my normal dreams: me and Krusty winning the
Wait a minute... If you’re here, then you've fallen asleep too!

Good-bye Lis.  I hope you get reincarnated as someone who can stay awake for fifteen minutes. From offscreen, we hear a PLUGGING SOUND and the bagpipe’s breathing stops abruptly. Willie’s eyes bulge out in horror.
Thanks to you, the nightmare’s over forever. The three get up and head outside to admire the sunrise.
I’ll save you, Dad. The sign for X, Y and Z Streets is bent over the black hole like a palm tree in a hurricane. Bart shimmies out to the end and extends his arm toward Homer.
Well, we hit a little snag when the universe sorta collapsed on itself... but dad seemed cautiously optimistic.
Wow, look at that Laramie car! I can't wait to start smoking Laramies!
Now get cracking on my long division. And don't forget to show your work, Simpson.
ke Yep, that’s the rule. He who tops it off, drops it off.
| See you in hell, brussel sprouts. No room for you, Jello.
Hey, everybody, vote for my Dad, Homer Simpson.  If you
What do we need church shoes for? Jesus wore sandals.
What a break, huh, Lis? Lisa grimaces and gingerly takes the sock from the tongs.
Hey, if you didn’t wanna tie shoes, you shouldn't have become a shoe salesman. Bart waggles the shoe impatiently. The clerk SIGHS and bends over to tie the shoe. His back makes a QUIET
The funniest man alive? The Prince of Pies? The Sultan of Seltzer?
Oh. Well, if you’re running this show, how could you leave

No, he’s alive. And he’s so funny you could plotz. At least according to his press release. Bart hands Jerry Krusty’s press release, which reads: "Local Clown Available for Hire." Along the bottom are tear-off tabs with Krusty’s phone number.
No, I was talking to Lisa back there, and we both agreed you killed.
Oh sure, there were a lot of laughs. You probably couldn’t hear them, the
Plus, they weren’t warmed up enough. Either that or they were all laughed out.
Clear the couch. It’s Krusty time! Bart CLICKS the remote.
This sucks. I’m outta here. Bart exits. From the TV, we hear a SPLAT.
That’s one of your posters. I have all the Krusty stuff. Krusty looks around the room at all the merchandise he’s
Well, they are! (CHANGING SUBJECT) Anyway, don’t you have some advice for Krusty?
Eat your vegetables. Take a sweater. I don’t think that’s a good idea.
Thank you. Thank you. And now, the all new comedy stylings of Krusty the
Krusty, the acoustics in here are just... Krusty cuts him off.
You got ‘em now, Krusty! Go for the kill. Flap that dickey! On TV, we see Krusty instinctively reach for his dickey string, then think better of it and push his own hand down as the APPLAUSE builds.
All right! I don’t know what’s going on here, but when you mix Krusty and fire, you can’t go wrong.
Krusty, doesn’t this go against everything you've been saying? Krusty covers the mic with his hand and leans down to Bart.
All right! We eat tonight! Bart YANKS on the pole and pulls in a large fish.

dialogue: Mom and Dad have been smooching again. Homer enters in an impeccably tailored three-piece suit, massaging his scalp. His hair is parted in the middle and slicked straight back. He checks his reflection in the oven door, licks his fingers and straightens out his eyebrow hair.
Well, as Mrs. Krabappel already mentioned, the name of the book that I read was "Treasure Island".
It's about these pirates. Pirates who wear patches over their eyes... and shiny gold teeth... and parrots on their shoulders...

And the pirates live on an island. But not just any island. It's an island filled with many, many different treasures... hence the title, Treasure Island. Did I mention this book was written by a man named Robert Louis Stevenson,  the famous author of "Kidnapped?"
So in conclusion, on the Simpsons' scale of ten, ten being the highest, I give this book... a nine. Bart writes a big "9" on the board.
Why certainly. The name of the pirate would be one... Bluebeard.
All right, one more hour and we hit the books.

Hey man, what's the big idea? You covered up my paper. Bart walks over to the refrigerator and pulls the test off the door. We see that it was covering up a yellow, dog- eared drawing of a CAT next to a tree -- Bart's sole contribution to the door. It is signed "Bart - lst Grade."
All right, okay, time for a little action here, let's take care of some business.  "Chapter One: A s
I am, Otto-man. Do you know anything about Pilgrims? oTTto
Okay, no reason to panic. Find an egghead, charm them for a couple of answers, boom, we're back on easy street. Bart spots the twins, SHERRY AND TERRY.
Good morning, girls. I don't know which one of you looks lovelier.
You don't say? And what about that history test?...  Piece of cake, huh? So let me ask you this? What did you get for Number one? Uh huh. And Number two?... Number three?...
Here you go, Mrs. Krabappel. I think you'll be pleasantly surprised. Krabappel pulls out her red pen and begins to grade it.
Look, you can't squeeze blood from a turnip. Why do you want me to say?! I'm dumb, okay? You think I'm happy about it?
What! You can't hold me back. I'll do better, I promise.
No, I mean it. You can't hold me back. I swear I'm gonna do better. Look at my eyes. See the sincerity, see the conviction, see the fear. As God as my
So they told me this was my final warning. Absolutely no more chances. Either I shape up on the next test or they are going to hold me back.
No, they really mean it this time. What am I gonna do?
Otto, you know I respect you. I mean you always let us throw stuff at cars and try to tip the bus on sharp turns... oTTo Hey man, I was there myself once. What's in your head, little man?
Well, I've been failing a lot of tests recently. otto Yuh huh.
And now they tell me that if I don't shape up they are going to hold me back in the fourth grade. otto That's it? Hey, relax, man. It's not
Hey, Martin... are you deaf? I said little help! Throw me the ball,
I need you to help me get a passing grade.
I mean I'll make it so that the other kids don't laugh at you so much.

Oh, yeah.  I guess it would be over there. Bart points to a corner where something resembling a desk is located. It is covered with candy wrappers, laser guns and small boxes of ammunition. Martin shakes his head.
Only geeks sit in the front seat. From now on you sit in the back row.
Because if you sit in the front, people can see the back of your head. You're a prime target for paper clips bouncing off your skull and spitballs dripping down your neck.
Great, Martin. Now the big test is tomorrow. What do you say we...

This is hopeless. I guess if you don't know history you're doomed to repeat the fourth grade. He SIGHS heavily and looks up at the stars. He crosses to the bed, gets down on his knees. Unseen by him, Lisa watches from the doorway.

Well, old timer... I guess this is the end of the road. I know I haven't been a decent, normal kid. But if I have to go to school tomorrow, I'll fail the test and be held back. I just need one more day to study. I need your help.
A teacher's strike, a power failure, a blizzard. Anything that'll cancel school tomorrow. I know it's asking a lot, but if anyone can do it, you can.
My God, she's right. What was I thinking of? I've asked for a miracle and now I've received it. For this I will study. Study as I've never studied before.

I'm not missing anything. Frozen earlobes, snowballs down the back of the neck, trudging up that stupid sled hill over and over again... how good could it be? Bart OPENS his window shade and looks outside.
Hey! Maybe just one snowball. He OPENS the window and is about to step out as he is hit in the face with a snowball. Martin approaches packing another one.
Do you want to be held back a grade? Concentrate.
No, you don't understand. I really tried this time. I really tried.
You know... 1754, the famous defeat to the French... Mrs. Krabappel looks up the statistic in her textbook.
Yeah, well that and a dime will get you a cup of coffee.
I got a D minus. I got a D minus. Look out fifth grade, here I come.
Come on man, do it! Do the blood thing! Come on, do it! Do it! Do it! Do it! Do it! Do it! Do it! Lisa is talking to another wall in the house.
Well that last story was just a warm-up for this  macabre tale, which I call, "Hungry Are The Damned."
Yeah, like when you look at "Friday The 13th, Part I," it's pretty tame by

I guess I'll have no trouble getting to sleep tonight. The kids exit the treehouse. We follow them out and down the ladder. They do not see Homer who is sitting on a tree branch looking petrified and BREATHING HEAVILY.
How 'bout if we just come back to the only bus in the lot?
What? Aren't we going to see any washed-up major leaguers?
Oh, wow -- there's Flash Bailor! I gotta get his autograph! He used to be a star!
Lousy, washed up, broken down... old tub of guts... who does...
Yes!!! Bart holds the ball up in his glove. Homer WHACKS the glove. The ball falls into Burns' glove. A thrilled Burns examines his prize.

Well, I'11 still be here in spirit. Whenever a kid flunks a test, I'll be there. Whenever there's a window broken and no one knows who did it, I'll be there. Whenever a doorbell rings and somebody goes to get it and nobody's there, I'll be there. And whenever someone's passing out garlic gum to his unsuspecting friends, I'll be there.
What's with this people? Why are they sitting on their hands?
Yes, yes. But just two weeks later, in a cage match --
Now, those are great seats. Hey, Milhouse, turn it up.
Mom, do we have to stay here and watch Dad get rescued? Can't we at least see the mud pull?
When I found what I was put on this Earth for.
Milhouse, the greatest thrill of my life was banging off that windshield. I'm searching for my next big stunt. It's out there somewhere. I can feel it in my bones.
Those cars give me an idea, but it's been done. The bus then passes a gully.
Otto, I'm gonna leap over Springfield Gorge on my skateboard.
Puttin' on my work clothes, Lis. Pretty dazzling, huh? How do you think I'll look hurtling over Springfield Gorge in these?

It's an honor, Lance. How are you feeling? Lance HUFFS and PUFFS, sweats and strains, as he struggles to lift his thumb to the "thumbs-up" position. He finally accomplishes this task in obvious agony. A loud CRACK is heard.

Hey, man, you can tell me not to do it, but there's no way you can watch me twenty-four hours a day. And the minute your back is turned, I'm grabbing my skateboard and heading for the gorge. Bart storms off to his room.
I've got to, Dad. I know I can do it.
No, Dad, you'll never make it. It's too windy, and the rocks are slippery, and sixty-three feet is a lot farther
Are you kidding? I'm terrified. The only thing that scares me more than certain death is all my friends calling - me chicken.
No way. I'd have to be an idiot to try something like that.
Hey, man, I don't want your stupid glue. Bart tosses the glue aside.

I know it wouldn't hurt ‘em to use some cartoons made in the last fifty years. Son, this is tradition. If you start building a balloon for every flash-in- the-pan cartoon character, you'd turn the parade into a farce.
It's broken, Mom.  Mon, it's broken.  Mom, it's t broken.  Mom, it's broken. Mom, it's broken.
Ah, cranberry sauce a la Bart. Bart exits. We stay on cranberry sauce.
Well it's taking up valuable real estate. He elbows it harder.
Okay. I'1l take some white meat and stuffing to go... and, ah, send up the pumpkin pie in about twenty minutes.
Dear Stupid Idiots... You have sent me to my room... for the last time... ever... in history. You will never... see me...  lay eyes on me... again. Your enemy... Bart Simpson.
Hey, boy! You're a good dog! You hate them, too, doncha? Come on, we don't need them to get a Thanksgiving dinner!
Hey, boy! Now I can buy us some food! The vagrants join hin.
No way, man. I came to America to escape oppression. Squanto glowers at him.
Hey, don't feel sorry for me, man. I told my dog I'd get us a Thanksgiving dinner, and by God, I did.
Naw, I got this place I hang out at. Bart and Santa's Little Helper take off.
I was a fool to come back here! Bart crosses to a trash can and climbs on top, which leads him to a tree branch, which he uses to bounce onto the roof.
No way am I gonna apologize. I don't have to, and I'm not gonna.
Okay, I'm sorry. And, Lisa... I'm sorry I made your centerpiece burn up.
Okay, let's quit foolin' around. Cash settlement.  Twelve big ones.
Lisa, how are you gonna grow up if you can't get used to people wrecking beautiful things?
I don't know! I don't know why I did it! I don't know why I enjoyed it! And I don't know why I'll do it again!
Yeah, well I don't happen to have a little cartoon character telling me right from wrong.
Hey everybody! Cranberry sauce! Right here! Help yourself! Marge takes a bottle over to Maggie.
Reliving past triumphs. What do you call those guys in chess that don't
Hey, man, this is the library! What are we doing here?
Okay, that's it! Now I know you're just pulling my chain.

I can't believe it... You've actually found a practical use for geometry. They move on to another hole, which features a seated Abe Lincoln statue, like at the Lincoln Memorial. Every few seconds, Lincoln's legs swing out at the knee in a very unnatural way, allowing an opening to hit the ball through. Lisa whips out a stopwatch and times it.
“Glory, glory, hallelujah / Teacher hit me with a ruler / Met her at the door with a loaded forty-four / And she ain't my teacher no more." Bart hits the shot, it goes right through Lincoln's legs.
Aim for the Octopus' third tentacle, allow for six inches of break.
Bank it off the pink tombstone, don't leave it short.
A state of bliss attained through the extinction of the self.

Homer, would you shut up about the tournament, already! Why are you so obsessed with it? You're crazy! Name me one athlete who got famous playing a sport with the word "miniature" in it, To hell with the tournament! I don't care about the stupid tournament!
Tree falling in the woods. Tree falling in the woods. Tree falling in the...
That reminds me. I've gotta get over to Milhouse's and... uh... play sports.
Me and the guys went fishing. Almost caught a catfish this big. (STRETCHES
Nuts. I was hoping it would be "Cupid Kneeling", which I consider to be a
What evil deeds? I admit I stole a couple of candy bars and cheated on a spelling test. But that's about all I've had time for so far. I'm only ten.

dialogue: Say... uh... is there anything I can do to avoid coming back here? Is there some way I can change my life?

dialogue: I did go away, Mom! I was miles and miles and miles away, writhing in agony in the pits of Hell. And you were there! And you! And you!

dialogue: Will I ever be able to clean my room again, Doc?

dialogue: Luckily, I was not killed that day. Although sometimes I wish I had been. cuT TO: The jury is SOBBING unashamedly. A number of the spectators are looking skeptical but are SNIFFING. Burns is scowling. Even the judge is frowning a little.

dialogue: Well, enjoy it while you can. Everything changes when you hit the big one-oh. Your legs start to go... candy
Sorry, this old timer does ramble on sometimes, don’t he?
Okay, it’s done! I/m doing it! Birthday gift coming your way!
Yes.  "Do you wet your pants?" Well, even the best of us has an occasional accident.
It does bring to mind the classic scalping scene from "Scratchy Goes Apache."
Hey, give it a rest. I’m on top of it. The check is in the mail.
Hey, you want that once a year empty gesture. You got it, sis.
Come on. If you’re really Michael Jackson, who were your last four dates for the Grammys?
What did you enjoy more -- acting in The Wiz with Diana Ross or writing We Are The World with Lionel Richie?
Great Caesar’s ghost, you are Michael Jackson. Can you stay on the line while I get all my friends and relatives?
Well, I guess I’m supposed to say "no." Uh-huh... New Bedlam Asylum... loves us... needs us... fears he may never see us again... Got it... Michael Jackson. Whoo-hoo! I love you, man.
Hey Mom, Dad’s in a mental institution. Bart hands her the message.
Yes Dad, I solemnly swear I will not tell another living soul... No, not even Milhouse.
You know, maybe you should trust that instinct and not ask.
Hey, Looney Tunes, this is what Michael Jackson looks like. You look like a big fat mental patient.
Wait, wait, Michael! You go sit at the piano and I’11 boil some coffee.
Lisa, her teeth are big and green / Lisa, she smells like gasoline / Lisa, da da da Deesa / She is my sis-ta, her birthday I missed-ta.

Yes, so it’s still technically your birthday in the Philippines. I hope you like your present. And a-one, and a-two, and a one, two, three, four -- Michael rolls in the piano and performs a song with Bart. Their SONG is a tribute to turning eight. Michael dances; he does a flashy move with his trademark fedora; Bart copies it using his lucky red cap. Marge, Homer and Maggie enter to enjoy the performance.

Hey! Where's the Frosty Krusty Flakes? * Aha! Lisa also opens and SLAMS cabinet doors looking for donuts. Homer, shaving with a cordless shaver, stands by the table, grabbing fried eggs with his hands and dropping them down his gullet. MAGGIE'S pupils bounce around as they follow the frenetic goings-on.
Yeah, who would possibly be late on meat loaf night?
Video library? You call one crummy - tape a library? tr
Look, lady, we've seen the Crappy Little Elves about fourteen billion times. Maybe we can watch some real
Awww, that's merely suggested viewing matter. Mom lets us watch whatever the hell we want.
Relax. This is cinema verite. When the brutal slow-motion killing starts, I'll tell you to shut your eyes.
I wish I could convey to you how truly sorry I am. Ms. Botz's silhouette descends on Bart.
We know who you are, Ms. Botz. Or should I say, Ms. Botzucowski. You're the Babysitter Bandit. Ms. Lotz drops Lisa next to Bart on the couch.
You're crazy if you think you're going * to get away with this, lady. You * can't --
This way to the scene of the crime, men. We've got her tied up in the den.
My turn. "Kwyjibo." K-W-Y-J-I-B-0. Twenty-two points. Plus triple word score. Plus fifty points for using all my letters. Game's over. I'm outta
Hey, Lis, keep an eye out for the guy with the peanuts.
"Toreador, oh don't spit on the floor. Please use the cuspidor, that's what it's for." Homer and Bart both GIGGLE.
No way a bull is gonna miss a target that big, man. Both CHUCKLE, stop, then look at each other and start
All right, Homer, come on, baby. Right across the plate-- let me feel the wind.
Yeah, well, you know...kinda... but I was thinking I could go undercover.

"My Proposal" by Bart Simpson. I want to pretend I am a regular dumb kid... period. By this I hope to achieve... No... For this I will require... Aw, man! He stops and thinks, scratches his head, chews his pencil, then violently erases everything he has written, smearing the paper and tearing a few holes in it. He continues on the same sheet.
"My Confession" by Bart Simpson. I am a regular dumb kid... period. I cheated on my intelligence test... period.
Dad... I gotta tell you something... I hope you won't be too mad...

I cheated on the intelligence test. I'm sorry. But I just want to say that the past few weeks have been great. Me and you have done stuff together, you've helped me out with things, and we're closer than we've ever been. I love you, Dad, and I think if something can bring us that close, it can't possibly be bad.
Oh, please, Mrs. Krabappel, not next to Wendell. He pukes on every bus ride. No offense, Wendell.

"They took Bart Simpson to the graveyard / And they buried him in the sand, oh, yeah / And every locomotive that comes roarin' by / Says, 'There lies a steel-drivin' man,' Lord! Lord! Oh, there lies a--"
Hey, Wendell, you made it, buddy. Bart SLAPS Wendell on the back.
Hey, there's my dad.  Hey, Dad! Yo, Homer! Homer looks around.
There's only one thing we can do. Take advantage of the old guy. You gotta sign my report card, Dad. Bart shows Homer a report card .
Yeah, they used to call that place Dead Man's Dip.
Yeah, man. Ever since Homer got his job back, he's never home on time. We HEAR FRONT DOOR OPEN and FOOTSTEPS approaching.
Hear that, Dad? You can lie around in your underwear and scratch yourself.
Careful, Dad. Blow a gasket and you lose your job.
If you really want to impress her, show her the big empty space where our TV used to be.
Hey, can you believe it, man? My sister has made a whole pile of cupcakes to butter up her teacher, and
This is the last time I ever worship a bus driver.
Better let me hold these, Lis. Bart tugs hopefully on his end of the box.
You teacher's pet! You sniveling toad! You little egg sucker!
All right, all right. Look. I'm sorry. I got upset. In the heat of the moment, I said some things I didn't mean.
Well, I'd have to say... your generous nature, your spirit of giving. Bart looks hopefully at the cupcakes and then at Lisa.
So give her back those cupcakes before I knock your block off.
It was an ACCIDENT, man. A terrible ghastly mistake! Ask anybody!
Okay, Nelson. Put up your dukes. We HEAR OMINOUS APPROACHING THUNDERING FOOTSTEPS and a
But I can't squeal. It would violate the code of the school yard.
Nelson, it was all a mistake. This is how it happened, man -- Listen up, you may get a kick out of it. -- My sister was baking cupcakes this morning and...

I'm gonna miss you, big guy. He then sits inside the bathtub, shrinking into a corner of the tub, WHIMPERING SLIGHTLY. This should be reminsicent of Anne Bancroft in The Graduate. Homer opens the bathroom door and sticks his head in.
No. He's pretty dumb. He's in all the same special classes I am.
Thanks, Pop. Homer gives the punching bag a terrific uppercut to the groin. SFX: HUGE PUNCH. The punching bag's eyes widen ever so slightly.
Whoa! Ouch! Ow! Ooh! Oh no, boys, not the can, please.
I need some advice, Grandpa. See, there's this bully at school who keeps beating me up.
Look everyone, that guy's been tormenting all of us for years. And I for one am sick of it. Kids AD LIB: "Huh", "Go on", "Let's hear more".
I can't promise you victory. I can't promise you good times, but the one thing I do know...
Whoa! Whoa! All right, okay. I promise you victory. I promise you good times. Kids CHEER.
Intelligence indicates he shakes down kids for quarters at the Arcade, then heads to the Quick-E-Mart for a cherry Squishee.
Two hundred rounds, sir. Is it okay if they say "Happy Birthday" on the side?
Nelson, I'm afraid I'm going to have to teach you a lesson.
Well, I guess you learned your lesson, so now I'll untie you.
Well... if that's going to be your attitude, I'm not going to untie you.

Ladies and gentlemen, boys and girls. Contrary to what you have just seen, war is neither glamorous nor fun. There are no winners, only losers. There are no good wars, with the following exceptions: the American Revolution, World War II, and the Star
If you would like to learn more about war, there's lots of books in your local library -- many of them with cool, gory pictures. Well, good night, everybody. Peace, man. Bart makes peace sign as we:
